newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico consumer group protests end of gas subsidy.
newsitem.headline: Mexico consumer group protests end of gas subsidy.

text.p: A Mexican consumer group on Friday criticized the planned scrapping of government subsidies on liquefied petroleum gas, saying the move would hit family budgets.
"We consumers face a serious threat that price controls on two basic items will be lifted," said Arturo Lomeli, president of the Mexican Consumer Defense Studies Association (AMEDEC).
Lomeli said the two products were liquefied petroleum gas for domestic use and tortillas.
Tortillas are corn pancakes that have been a staple part of the Mexican diet for many centuries. The government has denied any plan to lift tortilla subsidies.
The Mexican Energy Ministry has announced it will progressively eliminate subsidies on LP gas to bring its price up to international levels by around June or July.
Lomeli warned that lifting price controls on LP gas would "put pressure on prices of numerous products."
In view of impending price increases, Lomeli said, recent improvements on the macroeconomic front were not finding their way into family budgets.
